In a class on nonprofits at Stanford Business School, we had to check out the vision and mission statements of different organizations. As we went through over a hundred examples, we noticed something surprising: some of the biggest, most ambitious statements were actually the least inspiring. 

Take one that aimed to â€œeliminate hunger in the world.â€ With only five people in the group, that mission felt more like empty words than a real goal. 

Then, out of all that vague idealism, came a statement that really hit home. It was from Brad Pitt, the actor and social entrepreneur. After seeing how slow the recovery was for New Orleans post-Hurricane Katrina, he created an organization called â€œMake It Right.â€ Their clear goal? â€œTo build 150 affordable, green, storm-resistant homes for families in the Lower 9th Ward.â€ 

That statement changed the vibe in the room. The specific target made it feel real. And that realness? It was inspiring. It answered the key question: â€œHow will we know when we have succeeded?â€ ğŸŒŸ

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Evaluating nonprofit mission statements revealed that specific, concrete goals, like Brad Pitt's "Make It Right," are more inspiring than grandiose but vague ideals.
